claim: The post 'Analysing wind data with R' has only eight comments so far, not ten.
extra_info: the latest comment refers to MAX(CreationDate);
reasoning: The post 'Analysing wind data with R' (Id 7146) has CommentCount = 10 in the posts table, and COUNT(*) of comments in the comments table also returns 10. The claim asserts only 8 comments and explicitly denies 10, which is directly contradicted by the data.

content.text: I'll verify this claim by first exploring the database schema, then checking the number of comments on the post titled "Analysing wind data with R".

input.description: List all tables in the database

content.content:
badges       postHistory  posts        users      
comments     postLinks    tags         votes

tool_use_result.stdout:
badges       postHistory  posts        users      
comments     postLinks    tags         votes

content.content:
CREATE TABLE posts
(
    Id                    INTEGER          not null UNIQUE
        primary key,
    PostTypeId            INTEGER          null,
    AcceptedAnswerId      INTEGER          null,
    CreaionDate           DATETIME     null,
    Score                 INTEGER          null,
    ViewCount             INTEGER          null,
    Body                  TEXT     null,
    OwnerUserId           INTEGER          null,
    LasActivityDate       DATETIME     null,
    Title                 TEXT null,
    Tags                  TEXT null,
    AnswerCount           INTEGER          null,
    CommentCount          INTEGER          null,
    FavoriteCount         INTEGER          null,
    LastEditorUserId      INTEGER          null,
    LastEditDate          DATETIME     null,
    CommunityOwnedDate    DATETIME    null,
    ParentId              INTEGER          null,
    ClosedDate            DATETIME     null,
    OwnerDisplayName      TEXT null,
    LastEditorDisplayName TEXT null,
        foreign key (LastEditorUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (OwnerUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (ParentId) references posts (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.content:
CREATE TABLE comments
(
    Id              INTEGER          not null
        primary key,
    PostId          INTEGER          null,
    Score           INTEGER          null,
    Text            TEXT     null,
    CreationDate    DATETIME     null,
    UserId          INTEGER          null,
    UserDisplayName TEXT null,
        foreign key (PostId) references posts (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (UserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.text: Now let me find the post and count its comments:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT Id, Title, CommentCount FROM posts WHERE Title = 'Analysing wind data with R';"
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM comments WHERE PostId = 7146;"
input.description: Count actual comments for the post

content.text:
The results are clear:

- The post "Analysing wind data with R" (Id = 7146) has a `CommentCount` of **10**.
- Counting actual rows in the `comments` table for this post also gives **10**.
- The claim asserts the post has "only eight comments, not ten." The data shows it has exactly 10 comments, not 8.

The claim says the post has 8 comments and explicitly denies it has 10, but the database shows it has 10 comments. The claim is contradicted.

```json
{"label": "CONTRADICTED", "reasoning": "The post 'Analysing wind data with R' (Id 7146) has CommentCount = 10 in the posts table, and COUNT(*) of comments in the comments table also returns 10. The claim asserts only 8 comments and explicitly denies 10, which is directly contradicted by the data."}
```
